docs.lead_paragraph: KwaZulu/Natal, the province worst afflicted by AIDS, will make antiretroviral drugs available immediately to all pregnant women, whatever their infected status, Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi told Parliament, in an open split with cabinet colleagues. Government policy has been to provide the drug Nevirapine at 18 national test sites, but Mr. Buthelezi, said availability should extend even to areas where H.I.V. testing is impossible. The province began extending antiretrovirals beyond the test clinics last month.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Anti-AIDS Drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: Labor laws have failed to protect women working in clothing factories who encounter ''persistent'' discrimination and abuse, including forced overtime and pregnancy tests, according to a report by Human Rights Watch. It says that the factories, some subcontractors for major American retailers, discriminate by refusing to hire those who are pregnant, or by denying health care to those who become pregnant. Although most major American retailers spell out worker rights, the report says some factories continue to flout them. David Gonzalez (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Job Bias Report

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies who gain weight too quickly in their first four months appear prone to being overweight later in childhood, a new study reports. The researchers, led by Dr. Nicolas Stettler of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and the University of Pennsylvania, found that how quickly children gained weight early in life was a a better predictor of how heavy they would be at age 7 than other measures, including their weight at birth or at age 1. For each extra 100 grams (about 3.5ounces) they put on in a month, the risk of being overweight later increased by about 30 percent.

headline.main: Early Signs of Problems With Weight

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey ranked third lowest in the nation in the rate of births to teenage mothers in 1999, according to a survey released last week. The Kids Count survey, released by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, a private charitable organization working for disadvantaged children, found that in 1999, the most recent year for which figures are available, 7.4 percent of births in New Jersey were to mothers under the age of 20. In Massachusetts the rate was 6.9 percent and in New Hampshire, 7.1 percent. The highest percentage was 19.7 percent in Mississippi. The national average was 12.3 percent. The figures were little changed from the year before, in which New Jersey and New Hampshire were tied for second lowest after Massachussets. Karen DeMasters

docs.lead_paragraph: Strip away the trimmings and you will find that the essential structure of all living things, from the dainty amoeba to the boisterous elephant, from the stately elm to Donald Rumsfeld, is an alimentary system supporting a reproductive system. Why or even how this of all possible arrangements should exist defies ordinary human understanding. But it is plain to see that in the great game of survival every living thing must eat in order to replicate itself and so sustain the precarious grip of its species on its place in nature. What strong desires impel this behavior among the lesser sentient creatures we can only imagine. We may assume, however, that these other living things, unlike ourselves, rely upon instinct to moderate their hunger and lust, for unregulated desire means conflict and eventual extinction. But for us, when we encounter a pretty face or fowl, the moderating instinct is not nearly as dependable, if dependable at all. Hence our collective willingness, older than recorded time, to rely upon priests, magistrates and sacred texts to govern our appetites: a survival strategy embedded in our laws and rituals and known as civilization, a strategy that our fellow creatures, governed by instinct, can forgo. Of the modern holidays erected upon the relics of ancient rites, by which we still celebrate the rebirth of the sun at the winter solstice; spare the gravid ewes when we say farewell to meat at carne vale; rejoice in the resurrection of the fields at Easter; and tremble at nature's deathlike sleep in autumn, the celebration of eros occurs in mid-February, when, according to Geoffrey Chaucer, ''[it] was on seynt Volantynys day Whan euery byrd comyth there to chese his make,'' instinct telling them that the lengthening days will soon be mild enough to sustain new life, hence the chicks and bunnies of our own Easter holiday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak had been invited by a group of scholars on this chilly January evening to give a talk at the Penniman Library of the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia. ''They have read Gayatri's paper,'' said Ms. Spivak, a professor in the humanities at Columbia University who sometimes refers to herself in the third person. ''And they said they couldn't understand it.'' Ms. Spivak, wearing a sari, with vivid pink highlights in her crewcut hair, looks a little like Grace Jones. She originally wrote the paper, called ''Moving Devi,'' as a catalog essay for a 1999 museum exhibition of representations of Devi, the divine female principle in Hindu mythology.

headline.main: Creating a Stir Wherever She Goes

docs.lead_paragraph: He was their first child, and Ana and Giovanni Vargas feared they might lose him even before birth. Doctors discovered a heart valve defect and called the pregnancy high-risk. But little Gianni was born full-term by Caesarean section on Jan. 30, weighing almost 8 pounds. Then his parents worried about whether he would survive delicate corrective heart surgery last Saturday. They were thrilled when the operation was declared a success and doctors said he would go home in a week or so.

headline.main: Baby Dies In Hospital, And Parents Plan to Sue

docs.abstract: Ana and Giovanni Vargas give notice that they will sue Stony Brook University Hospital in Stony Brook, NY, over death of their infant child Gianni, who was given wrong dosage of potassium chloride at hospital (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Administration Plans Care of Fetuses in a Health Plan'' (news article, Feb. 1): As early as 1941, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's Bureau of Public Assistance determined that unborn children could be covered under the Social Security Act of 1935. When Medicaid was instituted, many states adopted similar eligibility definitions. These precedents are important as we look for ways for all women to receive prenatal care.
docs.abstract: Health Sec Tommy G Thompson letter on Feb 1 article holds Bush administration plan to cover fetuses under Children's Health Insurance Plan is aimed at providing prenatal care and is not part of abortion debate
